comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: This looks like a Junkers W33, registration D-1198. "On April 12–13, 1928, W33 D-1167 Bremen flew from Baldonnel near Dublin in Ireland to Greenly Island off Labrador in 37 hrs." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Junkers_W_33 I claim my prize of a glass of pop and a sticky bun.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] It is indeed a W33. It's the Europa. The second (backup) plane that Fitzmaurice and co brought along for the German-backed East-West transatlantic attempt. (Fitzmaurice's Irish-backed attempt the year before had to turn back when the "Princess Xenia" hit bad weather. The Junkers proved a better long-distance workhorse than the Fokker.) (FYI - Carol - when you're back, the catalogue record for this image has the wrong date. 1924 couldn't be right - as that plane wasn't built yet :) Enjoy the break from us persnickety types :) ).

comment._content: Have a lovely break you deserve it.

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: This would appear to be the triumphant arrival back at Baldonnel aerodrome on July 3rd 1928 of Fitzmaurice, Koehl and Huenefeld in the sister ship to the Bremen, the Europa, after their tour of Germany following their historic first East West crossing of the Atlantic. The Irish Independent reported: “Remerkable scenes were witnessed at Baldonnel aerodrome and in the city. When the Europa landed at Baldonnel, the people broke through the cordon of troops and rushed wildly to the machine. For a time the three airmen were unable to leave the plane. Captain Koehl appealed in vain to the people to keep back. Finally troops succeeded in clearing a space for the visitors. They were carried shoulder high to one of the hangers.”

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Fantastic, Bob! The only time people rush wildly at planes nowadays is to try and get a seat...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
